overview: From 2025-09-07 to 2025-09-14, ethereum-optimism/op-geth had 4 new PRs (2 merged), 1 new issues, and 48 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Abnormal CPU usage with latest op-geth ( v1.101511.0 )
topIssues.author: cpuchainorg
topIssues.body:
#### System information

Geth version: [v1.101511.0](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/releases/tag/v1.101511.0)
CL client & version: e.g. lighthouse/nimbus/prysm@v1.0.0
OS & Version: Ubuntu
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour

CPU usage should be same with the previous version ( [v1.101503.4](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/tree/v1.101503.4) )

#### Actual behaviour

It consumes like half of the CPU resources per node, which makes 100% if runs two node. On modern AMD CPU which should have less than 5% of usage in usual

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Observe CPU usage of op-geth after sync finishes

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````

When submitting logs: please submit them as text and not screenshots.

topIssues.title: op-geth init with large genesis file, level db panic
topIssues.author: cliff0412
topIssues.body:
i have a large genesis file, which is around 7 GB. 

i run below command to init db
```
./build/bin/geth --datadir data --gcmode=archive --db.engine=leveldb init --state.scheme=hash genesis.json 
```
the trieDB is committed succesfully; however, the `rawdb.WriteGenesisStaateSpec` throws error `panic: snappy: decoded block is too large`

the error message is clear that leveldb does not allow write such a big value. however, since my genesis file is very large, how to write such a big value to levelDB?

i think wring a 7 GB value to level db as one key value is not appropriate; possible to redesign it that it can be saved in multiple keys?

topIssues.title: Receipt Correction: Failed to decode RLP receipts ( v1.101602.0 )
topIssues.author: cpuchainorg
topIssues.body:
#### System information

Geth version: v1.101602.0
CL client & version: op-node v1.13.6
OS & Version: Ubuntu host with Docker
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

Network: op-mainnet during full sync

#### Expected behaviour

Should not crash with Receipt Correction error during sync


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Geth options

```
      --op-network="op-mainnet"
      --rollup.historicalrpc="https://mainnet.optimism.io"
      --rollup.sequencerhttp="https://mainnet-sequencer.optimism.io"
      --rollup.disabletxpoolgossip="true"
      --syncmode="snap"
      --state.scheme="path"
      --history.logs="0"
      --history.transactions="0"
```

op-node options

```
      op-node
      --network="op-mainnet"
      --syncmode="execution-layer"
      --l1.rpckind="standard"
      --l1.trustrpc
```

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````

When submitting logs: please submit them as text and not screenshots.

topPRs.title: all: Introduce feature toggles for Jovian
topPRs.author: geoknee
topPRs.body:
Allows feature to be easily removed from Jovian hardfork. When the hardfork scope is locked, this commit can be reverted.

Pairs with https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17424

topPRs.title: core: Log DA usage estimates
topPRs.author: sebastianst
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Adds logging of DA usage for each processed block. Only used to debug the DA footprint analysis, not intended to be merged.

topPRs.title: sync-superchain: Handle case where skipped genesis file doesn't exist
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Modify the sync-superchain.sh script to not error if a non-standard genesis file isn't actually available when trying to delete it.

Makes it possible to check kona prestates by converting the superchain-registry at a particular commit to the geth format. The celo genesis hasn't always been present so was causing conversion to fail.  While not ideal to use the latest conversion script from op-geth to convert an arbitrary superchain-registry commit, it seems far less brittle than attempting to parse the custom JSON kona converts the superchain-registry content to and be able to compare that with the go version accurately.

If the registry or this script changes in an incompatible way in the future, we may have to manually check compatibility of older kona-prestates or adjust the check-prestates tool to handle it, which isn't a big deal. We generally only need to check relatively recent prestates as well and worst case we could just tag a new kona release with an updated superchain-registry.
